context: From the period of 1600, the canton consisted of a <a0_0><b5_0>St George's Cross<b5_0/><a0_0/> representing the Kingdom of England. With the Acts of Union <a2_0><b7_0>1707<b7_0/><a2_0/>, the canton was updated to be the new Union Flag—consisting of an English St George's Cross combined with a Scottish <a1_0><b6_0>St Andrew's cross<b6_0/><a1_0/>—representing the Kingdom of Great Britain. After the Acts of Union <a3_0><b8_0>1800<b8_0/><a3_0/> that joined Ireland with Great Britain to form the <a4_0>United Kingdom<a4_0/>, the canton of the East India Company flag was altered accordingly to include a Saint Patrick's Saltire replicating the updated Union Flag representing the <b9_0>United Kingdom<b9_0/> of Great Britain and Ireland.
